diff_hunk:
@@ -1,9 +1,9 @@
-#! /usr/bin/env node
+#!/usr/bin/env nodejs
body: This breaks anything non-ubuntu. Definitely not a a good idea.

diff_hunk:
@@ -1,9 +1,9 @@
-#! /usr/bin/env node
+#!/usr/bin/env nodejs
body:
I agree with you on this, in fact I made a separate commit for this to help other Ubuntu users to solve the problem (a symlink is good too).
I did not know how to exclude a commit from a pull request... is it possible? :)
Should be a full indent here, no?

The last line ?? Yeah .. sure... sorry my emacs setup is for a slightly
different indentation style, and while I tried to keep it consistent, I
guess I missed that one.

## 

T
Yeah, I've made the same mistake while working on uglifyjs before. It isn't easy to remain consistent with the awkward 8-space indentation style.
What about the slash, is it forbidden or not?  (it's missing from my commit)
Ah yes, `/` is forbidden after `</script`. I think my suggested regex (where I forgot the `$1`) had it. I’ll add it in another commit.
Man, this is unfortunate.

Yeah, well, you can try it yourself — just uncomment that block (in `tighten`) and test it on jQuery.  The final size is 1K bigger.  It's really hard to decide what's best based on static analysis.  I guess jQuery is heavily hand-optimized, and we should let it be.

So that's why I decided to remove that optimization; without it my own code gets like 50 bytes fat (talking about 250K compressed), but jQuery loses 1K (talking about 90K compressed)—so I decided it's not worth to have it.  Also, after gzip I bet `return` ain't so bad, being omnipresent it must compress very well.  I didn't do any statistics after gzip though, feel free to do and share. ;-)

_Edit_: or we could make it optional...

I would think it must be the case that jQuery has a lot of functions that take early exits and then uglifyJS generates really long consecutive statements (with the comma operator), ultimately producing more verbose code. There must be a test we can do to see how many statements follow the early exit.

Did you mean to check the truthiness of these two values? If you're looking for existence, you should make it more clear: `binOp in binOpSwaps` or `node[3] != null` or whatever. It may be correct because you always know that the values in `binOpSwaps` will be truthy (and hopefully nobody ever changes `Object.prototype`), but it should still convey your intentions.
@michaelficarra True, that code was somewhat unclear. Is it better now?

I like it. I noticed it was the same as my examples. That was a coincidence, right? Because I was just listing some ways to check for property existence and gave no thought to what the actual desired check was.
Well, your examples sounded good, so I decided to use them.
I think this would be more readable as an array literal.
OK, done.
Can you explain this change to me? Why do you have to walk the `rvalue` before the `lvalue`?
Oh, alright. Thanks.

Why `~`? Bitwise operators are so 1985.

``` javascript
if (v[0] == '!' || v.indexOf('@license') > −1 || v.indexOf('@preserve') > −1) {
```
good point
What does this have to do with the pull request?
Nothing.  It just reports errors with context, which makes it far far easier to debug this sort of thing.
Shouldn't you then remove line 260?
I've removed this, for a cleaner pull request.
The patch looks good, thanks!  One thing, saving `directives` here is probably unnecessary — if we're parsing a function, then we're no longer inside directives above it, right?
Quite right! Fix forthcoming!
You'd still need `S.in_directives = false` here. ;-)
Good. :-)  Merged, thanks.
`Number.NaN` to `0/0`
There is no need to check whether `NaN` is bound in a Lexical Environment.
How about exporting `is_identifier_char` instead?

diff_hunk:
@@ -62,7 +62,8 @@ var jsp = require("./parse-js"),
     slice = jsp.slice,
     member = jsp.member,
     PRECEDENCE = jsp.PRECEDENCE,
-    OPERATORS = jsp.OPERATORS;
+    OPERATORS = jsp.OPERATORS,
+    UNICODE = jsp.UNICODE;
body: How about importing `jsp.is_identifier_char` instead?
`jsp.is_identifier_char` could be used instead.

Just like when it comes to the original code, this does not work when the next token starts with an escape sequence (cf. #420).
There is no need to test two whole strings, just the last character of the first one and the first character of the last one.
This could be split into `./test/unit/compress/test/issue420.js` and `./test/unit/compress/expected/issue420.js`.

diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,14 @@
+#! /usr/bin/env node
+
+var
+  jsp = require("../lib/parse-js")
+, pro = require("../lib/process")
+, source1 = "var ø = { \"getSelf\" : function () { return ø } }"
+, source2 = "if (typeof ø === \"undefined\") ; else ø.getSelf()"
body:
Incidentally, if `return` and `else` are combined with an identifier, so should `typeof`. However, this is not the case in UglifyJS 1.3.1.

``` bash
echo 'typeof[],function(){return[]};' | uglifyjs
```

yields

``` javascript
typeof [],function(){return[]};
```
